item.title: Tech Exchange
item.description: This series features conversations between FT journalists and the technology industry’s leaders, innovators, and thinkers. In the latest instalment, Chinese AI pioneer Kai-Fu Lee talks about the competition between the technology’s two superpowers

item.title: The Treasury market is treading in dangerous waters
item.description: Bank balance sheets lack capacity to intermediate the surging amount of trading in the US government bonds

item.title: Reading the runes on a Warsh Fed
item.description: The presumptive next chair might be better than others on the list, but he is a confusing, perhaps confused, figure

item.title: How copper miners are squeezing their way out of a shortage
item.description: With demand set to soar, the industry has got inventive over extracting the metal using leaching initiatives

item.title: The tyranny of targets
item.description: Not only is quantification changing our behaviour, but we’re failing to notice this has happened

item.title: Who killed the British flat?
item.description: The government needs to revive the appeal of flats — but capping ground rents at £250 a year won’t cut it

item.title: Can I ask my ex-husband for more financial support?
item.description: When we divorced he claimed he was struggling, but I now suspect him of transferring wealth to a relative

item.title: Everyone and their mother is peddling an AI application
item.description: We are either on the verge of widespread adoption or a terrible crash

item.title: Can Tesla make its own chips?
item.description: History suggests such a venture is particularly prone to value destruction

item.title: The new rules of finance, courtesy of Elon Musk
item.description: Merger of SpaceX and xAI epitomises the way Big Tech has turned the corporate world on its head

item.title: Iran’s people stand to lose whether or not talks succeed
item.description: Trump is not negotiating to ease the burden of the regime’s victims — and war will not make them safer

item.title: Under Prabowo, Indonesia is veering off course
item.description: Investors are jittery about the government’s fiscal and political record

item.title: Artemis is a throwback to the golden age of lunar exploration
item.description: This US programme must contend with the difficulties of returning humans to the Moon for the first time in more than 50 years

item.title: The Epstein rot goes deep
item.description: America must now ask itself if it can restore a culture of shame

item.title: The consumer sentiment puzzle deepens
item.description: The data is better; vibes are worse

item.title: No, the public is not irredeemably ignorant
item.description: But there is a disconnect between economists’ metrics and people’s perceptions

item.title: Scheming, joking, complaining: Moltbook’s AI agents are just like us
item.description: Like humans, rules will need to be set and comings and goings tracked, highlighting how managers will always be needed

item.title: UBI fans must remember a job is about more than the money
item.description: The value of work often gets left out of discussions about AI

item.title: Craft advertising lifts Lucky Saint’s non-alcoholic beer
item.description: The London brand has drawn on British marketing traditions for its irreverent image

item.title: It’s time for gardeners to ask some prickly questions about invasive species
item.description: We inherit gardens but not their histories. We love them but don’t always know how plants got there, what damage they might be doing, and what to do with that knowledge

item.title: Global investors need to go on Japan watch right now
item.description: Rises in government bond yields and weakness in the yen could have spillover effects on other markets

item.title: Devon Energy’s merger with Coterra looks a little too defensive
item.description: With oil prices stagnant and development costs high, investors seem none too impressed by this all-stock deal

item.title: This is what a proper Brexit looks like
item.description: Prosperity and security will be driven by removing unnecessary barriers that hold businesses back

item.title: American brands have lost their cool
item.description: As boycotts spread, the US is discovering the price of being politically unpopular

item.title: Xi’s ominous purge of his top general
item.description: President’s power play bodes badly whether it is a sign of strength or weakness
